hawaiian_text:
He aina hau kinikini o Kohala,

Naâ€™u i helu a hookahi hau,

A ehiku hau keu

O ke ama hau la akahi,

O ka iako hau la alua,

O ka ilihau la akolu,

O ka laau hau la aha,

O ke opu hau la alima,

O ka nanana hau la aona,

O ka hau i ka mauna la ahiku.
reference_translation:
The land of many hau trees is Kohala,

I have counted [out of] one hau tree,

And have found seven hau.

The hau for the outrigger makes one,

The hau for the iako makes two,

The bark of the hau makes three,

The wood of the hau makes four,

The bush of the hau makes five,

The large hau tree makes six,

The hau on the mountain makes seven.
mistral-Small-3.1-24B-ud-q4kxl-maui_tran:
The provided Hawaiian text appears to be a traditional or cultural poem or chant, which can be quite complex to translate directly into English due to its poetic and cultural nuances. However, I can provide a literal translation of the text to the best of my ability. Here is a possible interpretation:

<translation>
The finely woven land of Kohala,

I count one bundle,

And six bundles from me,

The first bundle of the anchor,

The second bundle of the crossbar,

The third bundle of the beam,

The fourth bundle of the timber,

The fifth bundle of the trunk,

The sixth bundle of the pattern,

The bundle on the mountain peak.
</translation>

Please note that this translation attempts to capture the literal meaning of the words but may not fully convey the poetic and cultural significance of the original Hawaiian text. For a more accurate and culturally sensitive translation, consulting a specialist in Hawaiian language and culture would be advisable.
